One or two bad games (unless they are really bad) won't net you a punishment. That coupled with the people who say "the reports are meaningless" to bait people into not doing it tends to convince some people that the automated system doesn't do anything. Take a look on boards though and you'll see it does in fact work. 

Bearing in mind of course that the majority of players who post about their punishments on boards are those that feel they were unjust. Most players who face punishments know exactly what they did wrong, and the vast majority never see a second punishment.

It's always frustrating to encounter a toxic player, especially if they are targeting you, but really the best advice we can give is to mute and report in post game. If they are acting out consistently they well face punishment for it, and if it was a once off then they at least have been flagged by the system in case they start doing it often.

It's also incredibly frustrating that there isn't more feedback to reporting players. Believe me this is my biggest pet peeve with the behaviour systems in place. The popup notifying you that someone you reported has been punished only shows up under very specific and very limited circumstances, so most players never see it. If you only reported things like severe hate speech you'd probably see it almost every report, but for the average player you'll almost never see it. This is indeed a failing of the system, however it doesn't mean that people aren't being punished, simply that players aren't being notified of it.

Lemme explain to you why the people that are wrongfully banned on the boards is not proof the system works.

By comparing to the legal system.

just because i catch 5 pedophiles, does not mean that i caught every pedophile in the world, or even half of them, or even 10% of them.

it means i caught 5.

Now imagine, if we had the ability to just know that someone might have committed a crime, but we decided that the best course of action was to let a computer decide if they are guilty.

I mean the legal system is pretty broken, but if you put a computer in charge of making every decision instead of a judge and jury... my god the number of false imprisonments and people who get away scott free would skyrocket.

because the computer doesnt feel, the computer cant read between the lines.

Thats why if i wanted to be toxic, id just send smiley faces all game to piss people off.

System cant catch that.

A human can though.

First of all, the variety of behaviours involved in the criminal justice system is an incredible amount more than that which is seen in game, which largely follows predictable patterns of behaviour, which is precisely why an automated system is effective at catching the _majority_ of cases. It is not designed to catch all of them, rather it is designed to catch all the standard behaviours, so that Riot can focus on the niche cases that need more context to determine.

Catching 5 pedophiles with 100% accuracy is still better than catching 5 pedophiles with 50% accuracy and rewarding the people that caught them regardless of accuracy, which is in essence the problem that tribunal had. It was accurate enough, and rewarded people for being salty/petty and witch hunt-y rather than voting for an objective punishment.

If you put a similar machine learning program in charge of say, petty theft cases then you would likely see an improvement, as it can take into account any history of crime and determine a punishment that fits the severity and the frequency of the crime in a fraction of the time the courts can, where the courts often don't have enough time to review cases properly, and end up putting petty thieves in jail for first time non violent offences.
___
The system can in fact catching you spamming smiley faces, and if you get reported for it you will face punishment eventually. There was a very similar case on NA, where someone was spamming a GG macro (the one with all the | lined up) everytime someone died and got chat restricted for it very quickly.

Even if you assume the system can't catch it, the number of report you would be receiving would tell the system that something isn't right, and it would pass your logs on for manual audit, which would then result in punishments.

peer moderation would mean the peers literally moderate the banning process.


Our only input is nominations for bans which then go through an automatic system that just checks a bunch of flags and decides whether that constitutes a ban.

A system which time and time again is proven to just not fucking work, because while it does ban SOME people, far more just go through the system unnoticed because they do things that arent accounted for in the variable check.

a real world example of this is that support singed.

Clearly he was getting hundreds of reports otherwise a rioter wouldnt have manually audited his account.

But the system didnt catch him.

Do i think he was wrongly banned? yes.

Do i think riot thinks he should be banned? yes.

Do i think riots own fucking system didnt do what riot thinks it does? yes.

Because lets face it, if riot actually thinks he should be banned, then their automatic system would be looking for the things that got him banned, and if thats the case why did it have to come to a manual audit to actually get him banned?

unless the system doesnt fucking work.


ive been playing league since open beta, so i actually have a point of reference where i can compare tribunal to non tribunal, because i was playing on na both during and post tribunal eras.

i am walking fucking evidence, that the tribunal works, because i remember god damn clearly that the game was less toxic before the tribunal got canned.

infact i remember when they announced this automatic system, talking it up like its the holy grail, guess what, games more toxic than when that announcement happened as well.

The automatic system only appears to work, because the people that try to defend it, are all high elo.

And the player pool in high elo is significantly smaller, so if you ban one troll out of a player base of a few thousand people, guess what, you just banned a significant portion of them.

Do that same thing in lower elos, where the toxicity problem still exists, and you didnt scratch the surface.

If it isn't reported, it isn't punished, therefore the act of submitting a report is saying "I think this is punishment worthy" and therefore constitutes moderation (even if it isn't as direct as you would like). Manual bans are done frequently but compared to the automatic system it is a rather small percentage. 

With that many cases reviewed and punishments handled how many false cases have you seen? I've seen one on OCE boards and two through the NA volunteers and all 3 were resolved within a week through support as is the norm. A false punishment will ALWAYS be reversed.

The Singed support case is not nearly so simple. The system didn't pick him up because it was a niche case, which are passed on for manual audits. It is a case that Riot would have been monitoring for a while given the number of reports he was receiving. It wasn't until he'd wracked up a significant number that Riot decided to take action which is when it hit the spotlight. When he was punished does not equal when he was noticed.

Do I think he was wrongly banned? No. I have discussed this extensively in other posts so I will not repeat my reasoning here.

Do I think Riot wanted to ban him? Yes, but temporarily. I do not believe the threat of perma was warranted and also believe it was largely due to miscommunication within support rather than any real danger of being perma banned.

Do I think Riot's system works? Yes.
Does it pick up niche cases? No, but that's what the manual audits are for. Is it perfect? No, but it does far better than tribunal ever did, in terms of accuracy, reform rates, and overall approval of punishments by the community.

Support Singed is so niche it basically never happens, which is precisely why the automated system can't see him. The automated system is a machine learning system, i.e it requires previous cases to understand if a player needs a punishment or not. Since it didn't have enough history to evaluate the Singed, it didn't, and simply flagged it for manual review.

Expecting the automated system to be able to accurately punish the support Singed is like asking a kid who's seen a car once to drive it for you. It just doesn't work that way.

In case you were unaware, high elo is WAY more toxic than bronze, and due to the high saturation of smurfs, it's hard to actually permanently ban a player. High elo is where witch hunting is at its worst. Get on someone's bad side and they'll be queue sniping you and trolling you until they run out of accounts or get over themselves enough to leave you be.

The people who defend the system are those who see it working. Who look at all sides (those getting banned that should be, those getting banned that shouldn't, those not getting banned that should be and those not getting banned that shouldn't) and decide that there is sufficient evidence for them to conclude it works. 

Clearly you are one of the people that don't believe there is sufficient evidence, and that is the biggest reason why I want more stats form the punishment systems, but Riot has it's issues with transparency like any other company. They do a lot better than most.
